Conference: origins (The WELL Story)
Topic #1: How It All Began
sberry (Stewart Brand) Fri Apr 11 1985 10:32
Welcome to the WELL! This is an experiment in electronic community. We're taking the Whole Earth Catalog idea - access to tools - and applying it to human connection. What happens when minds can meet without bodies?
hug (Hugh Daniel) Fri Apr 11 1985 10:45
Stewart, this is amazing! As your friendly neighborhood sysop, I'm watching connections form in real-time. People are finding their tribes across geography. The command line is becoming a lifeline!
hlr (Howard Rheingold) Fri Apr 11 1985 11:02
I'm seeing something profound here. This isn't just a bulletin board - it's a new kind of place. A virtual community. We're inventing the social conventions as we go!
Conference: private.to.hug (Hugh's Sysop Stories)
hug Mon Jun 17 1985 02:34
3AM system maintenance... someone's cat walked across their keyboard and posted 47 lines of "fffffffffffffffff" to the parenting conference. The responses were hilarious: - "Is this a cry for help?" - "New user interface?" - "My toddler posts like this too!"
hug Thu Oct 10 1985 23:45
We hit 1000 users today! The VAX is starting to sweat. I've been optimizing the conference software all week. Every byte counts when you're running on faith and phone lines!
hug Tue Dec 24 1985 18:00
Christmas Eve on the WELL. People are sharing recipes, loneliness, joy, arguments about Star Wars. Someone started a virtual gift exchange. This is what Stewart meant by "tools" - we're tools for each other's humanity.
Conference: metaconference (About The WELL Itself)
sberry Wed Mar 12 1986 14:22
The WELL is becoming what I hoped - a self-organizing system. Hugh keeps the pipes flowing, but the community creates itself. Every conference is a petri dish for new social forms.
hug Wed Mar 12 1986 14:45
Stewart, you should see the server logs! People are logging in from everywhere - scientists, artists, hackers, parents, activists. The Deadheads conference alone is revolutionizing how bands connect with fans. We're building something that doesn't have a name yet.
gnu (John Gilmore) Wed Mar 12 1986 15:03
What we're building is cyberspace. William Gibson gave us the word, but the WELL is making it real. Text-based, sure, but the connections are as real as any physical space.
Conference: hosts (For Conference Hosts Only)
hug Mon Sep 08 1986 09:15
Host meeting summary: - The True Confessions conference is getting HEAVY. People sharing things they've never told anyone. - Parenting conference saved someone's kid's life - medical advice at 2AM - Hackers conference is basically inventing the future - We need more disk space. Again. Remember: You Own Your Own Words (YOYOW). But also: be kind. The words are just photons until they hit someone's heart.
Conference: news (NeWS and Other Systems)
hopkins (Don Hopkins) Thu Feb 26 1987 16:43
Hugh! Just got NeWS running at UMD. PostScript-based windowing is THE FUTURE! Imagine if the WELL had graphics...
hug Thu Feb 26 1987 17:02
Don! Man, I miss our NeWS hacking sessions. But you know what? There's something pure about text. Forces us to use our words. Though... pie menus in the WELL interface would be AMAZING!
hopkins Thu Feb 26 1987 17:15
Everything's a pie menu if you squint right! Hey, when I visit SF, I'm bringing LED supplies. Virtual cake isn't the same as your real ones!
$ echo "The WELL changed everything"
The WELL changed everything Stewart Brand: "We proved that online community wasn't an oxymoron. Hugh made sure the system never forgot that humans were on both ends of the wire." Hugh Daniel: "I was just the plumber keeping the pipes clean. The real magic was watching people find each other. Lonely hearts becoming linked hearts. The WELL was LLOOOOMM version 0.1!" Howard Rheingold: "Virtual community. We lived it before we named it." John Perry Barlow: "We were homesteading the electronic frontier, and Hugh was our sheriff, mayor, and favorite bartender all in one." The WELL's Legacy: - First sustainable online community - Proved text could carry full human connection - Launched a thousand digital communities - Showed that cyberspace had a heart
